Good man!

I will not remain in the world for the sake of unconditioned sentient beings.

As for Ajatashatru, it refers to those who are fully endowed with afflictions and so forth.

Ajatashatru refers to the queens and concubines in King Ajatashatru's harem and all the women of Rajagriha.

Ajatashatru means non-arising;

for means unstained;
because it is unstained by the eight worldly dharmas, for immeasurable, limitless, incalculably long eons it does not enter nirvana.

Good man!

The Tathagata's secret words are inconceivable, the Buddha Dharma and the Sangha are also inconceivable, the Bodhisattva-mahasattva is also inconceivable, and the Mahayana Mahaparinirvana Sutra is also inconceivable.
At that time, the World-Honored One, the Great Compassionate Guide, entered the Moon Love Samadhi for King Ajatashatru.

The light was cool and refreshing, illuminating the king's body, and his wounds were immediately healed, and the heat and sweat were eliminated.
The king felt his wounds healed and his body refreshed, and said to Jivaka:

'When the eon is about to end, the three months appear together.

The king asked again:

Great King, you should know:
This is the light emitted by the Heaven of Heavens.

This light has no root, no bounds, it is neither hot nor cold, neither permanent nor ceasing, neither form nor formless, neither characterized nor uncharacterized, neither blue nor yellow, neither red nor white.
In order to liberate sentient beings, it makes the visible, characterized, with roots, bounds, heat, cold, blue, yellow, red, and white.
Great King!
Although this light is like this, it is truly indescribable and invisible, and there is no blue, yellow, red, or white.
The king said:
Jivaka!
What causes and conditions led the Heavenly among Humans to emit this light?
Jivaka replied:
This auspicious sign is for the great king.
Because the king said earlier:
'In the world, there is no good doctor to treat the body and mind.'
Therefore, he emitted this light to first cure the king's body, and then his mind.
The king said:
Jivaka!
Does the Tathagata, the World-Honored One, also think of me?
Jivaka replied:
It is like a person with seven children. If one of the children falls ill, the parents' minds are not unequal, but they are more concerned about the sick child.
Great King!
The Tathagata is also like this. He is not unequal towards sentient beings, but he is more concerned about those who commit offenses.
The Buddha has compassion for the negligent,
but he abandons those who are not negligent in their minds.
Who are those who are not negligent?
It refers to the bodhisattvas of the six abodes.
Great King!

The World-Honored Buddhas do not consider the age, whether old, young, or middle-aged, the poverty or wealth, the time, day, month, or lunar mansion, the craftsmanship, lowliness, servants, or maids of sentient beings, but only consider those sentient beings who have a good mind.

Great King, you should know:
Such auspicious signs are the light emitted by the TathÄgata entering the samÄdhi of moon-like love.

Great King!
It is like the moonlight that can bring joy to the hearts of all travelers;

The king said to JÄ«vaka:

Great King!

It is like a thirsty person rushing to clear springs, a hungry person seeking food, a frightened person seeking rescue, a sick person seeking a good doctor, a hot person seeking shade, a cold person seeking fire - your seeking of the Buddha should be like this.

The TathÄgata still expounds the essential Dharma for icchantikas and the like, let alone the great king who is not an icchantika, who should not be saved by the compassionate rescue?
The king said:
JÄ«vaka!

Why does the TathÄgata expound the Dharma for them?'
JÄ«vaka replied:
Great king!

It is like a person who encounters a serious illness. This person dreams at night of ascending a one-pillar hall, eating ghee, oil, and applying it to the body, lying in ashes, eating ashes, climbing a withered tree,

or playing and sitting with a monkey, sinking in water and mud, falling from a tower, a high mountain, a tree, an elephant, a horse, or an ox, wearing clothes of blue, yellow, red, or black, laughing, singing, and dancing.
Or they see crows, vultures, foxes, and other such creatures, with their teeth and hair falling out, naked, pillowing on dogs, lying in filth.

After the person has had this dream, their mind becomes sorrowful.

Because of the increased illness, the family members send a messenger to the doctor.
The messenger sent has an incomplete physical form, incomplete faculties, a head covered in dust, wearing tattered clothes, riding an old broken cart, and says to the doctor:
'Quickly get in the cart.'
At that time, the good doctor thinks to himself:
'Now seeing the messenger's inauspicious appearance, I know that the patient is difficult to cure.'
He thinks again:
'Although the divination is inauspicious, I should still consult the calendar to see if it is curable.
If it is the fourth, sixth, eighth, twelfth, or fourteenth day, the illness will also be difficult to treat.'
He thinks again:
'Although the day is inauspicious, I should still consult the stars to see if it is curable.
If it is the star of Mars, Venus, Pleiades, King Yama, Mercury, or Jupiter, the illness will also be difficult to treat.'
He thinks again:
'Although the stars are inauspicious, I should still observe the time.
If it is autumn, winter, sunset, midnight, or moonset, one should know that the illness will also be difficult to treat.'
He thinks again:
'Although these various signs are inauspicious, they may or may not be definitive. I should observe the patient.

If there is no merit, what benefit is there in being fortunate?'
Having thought this, he went with the messenger. On the way, he thought again:

On the way ahead, he saw two small children pulling each other, fighting, grabbing each other's heads, pulling out each other's hair, and hitting each other with tiles, stones, knives, and sticks.

He saw people cutting down trees.
He saw people dragging leather with their hands and walking along the road.
He saw things dropped on the road.
He saw people holding empty vessels.
He saw monks walking alone without companions.

Having seen these things, he thought again:
'The messengers sent and the various signs seen along the way are all inauspicious. Know that the patient's illness is difficult to cure.'
He further thought:
'If I do not go, then I am not a good doctor;
if I do go, I cannot save him.
' He further thought:
'Although these various signs are inauspicious, I will set them aside and go to the patient.'
Having contemplated this, he further heard such sounds along the way, namely, loss, death, collapse, destruction, peeling, falling, burning, not coming, incurable, and unable to rescue.
He further heard the sounds of flying birds in the south, namely the sounds of crows, vultures, and Å›Ärika birds, as well as dogs, rats, foxes, pigs, and rabbits.
Having heard these sounds, he further thought:
'Know that the patient's illness is difficult to cure.'

At that time, I immediately entered the patient's house and saw that the patient had frequent chills and fevers, pain in the bones and joints, red eyes with tears flowing, hearing sounds outside with the ears, throat constricted and painful, the tongue cracked on the surface, the complexion was dark, the head could not support itself, the body was withered and without sweat, the bowels and bladder were obstructed and not passing, the body suddenly became fat and large, red and unusual, the voice was uneven, sometimes coarse and sometimes fine, the whole body was mottled with different colors, blue and yellow, the abdomen was swollen and full, and the speech was incoherent.

'What was the patient's state of mind like yesterday?'
He replied:
'Great teacher!
The person originally had faith and respect for the Three Jewels and various gods, but now it has changed and the feeling of faith and respect has ceased.

His original nature was kind, filial, and respectful to his parents, but now he has no respect for his parents.'

Having heard this, the doctor went forward to smell him. He smelled the fragrance of utpala flowers, agarwood, bakula flowers, tagara flowers, tamalapatra flowers, saffron, and sandalwood, as well as the smell of burning meat, the smell of jujube wine, the smell of burning sinews and bones, the smell of fish, and the smell of excrement.

Having discerned the smells, he then touched the body and felt that it was smooth and soft, like silk, cotton, or kapok flowers, sometimes rough like a stone, sometimes cold like ice, sometimes hot like fire, and sometimes rough like sand.
At that time, the skilled doctor, having seen these various signs, definitely knew that the patient would die without a doubt, but he did not say for certain that the person would die.
He told the nurse:
'I have urgent business now and will come again tomorrow.
Whatever is needed, give it to him without restriction.
' He then returned home.

The wise should know that such a patient will certainly die without a doubt.
Great King!
The World-Honored One is also like this. He skillfully understands the capacities of icchantikas and preaches the Dharma for them.
Why is it so?
If he does not preach for them, all ordinary people will say:
'The Tathagata has no great compassion.'
One who has compassion is called omniscient;
if he has no compassion, how can he be called an omniscient person?
Therefore, the Tathagata preaches the Dharma for icchantikas.
Great King!
The World-Honored One, the Tathagata, sees the sick and always bestows the Dharma medicine.
If the sick do not take it, it is not the fault of the Tathagata.
Great King!
There are two kinds of icchantikas:

The TathÄgata skillfully knows that those of the icchantika class who are able to attain wholesome roots in the present will be taught the Dharma;

Therefore, the TathÄgata expounds the essential Dharma for the icchantikas.
There are two kinds of icchantikas:
first, those with sharp faculties, and second, those with middling faculties.
Those with sharp faculties are able to attain wholesome roots in the present life, while those with middling faculties will attain them in future lives.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, do not expound the Dharma in vain.

It is like a pure person who falls into a latrine. A good friend sees this and takes pity on them, immediately grabbing them by the hair and pulling them out.
The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are also like this. They see sentient beings who have fallen into the three evil destinies and use skillful means to rescue and deliver them, enabling them to escape.
Therefore, the TathÄgata expounds the Dharma for icchantikas.
The king said to JÄ«vaka:

Whether it is sandalwood fire or frankincense fire, both burn equally, without any difference.

At that time, the king ordered a minister named Auspicious and said to him:
Great Minister, you should know:
I now wish to go to where the World-Honored Buddha is and quickly prepare the necessary offerings.
The ministers said:
Great King!
Excellent, excellent!
All the necessary offerings are fully provided.
King Ajatashatru, together with his wife, prepared twelve thousand carriages.
There were fifty thousand mighty elephants, each with three people on it, carrying banners, canopies, flowers, incense, music, and various offerings, all complete.

Therefore, there is no closer condition than a good friend.
King Ajatashatru heard on the road that in Shravasti, King Vidudabha of Videha died in a fire on the sea while on a ship;
that the monk Kokalika was born and entered the earth to Avici Hell;
and that Sunakshatra, having committed various evils, went to the Buddha and was absolved of his many sins.
Having heard this, he said to Jivaka:

Come, Jivaka!
I want to ride an elephant with you.
If I am to enter Avici Hell, I hope you will hold me and not let me fall.
Why is this?
I have heard that those who have attained the Way do not enter hell.
At that time, the Buddha said to the great assembly:
King Ajatashatru still has doubts. I will now make his mind firm.
At that time, in the assembly there was a bodhisattva named Holder of All who said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has previously said:
'All dharmas have no fixed characteristics, namely, form has no fixed characteristics, up to nirvana also has no fixed characteristics.'
How can the Tathagata now say that he will make a firm mind for Ajatashatru?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
I will now definitely make a firm mind for King Ajatashatru.
Why is it so?
If the king's doubtful mind can be destroyed, then know that all dharmas have no fixed characteristics.
Therefore, I have given King Ajatashatru a determined mind, you should know that this mind is without determination.
Good man!
If the king's mind were determined, how could his rebellious crime be destroyed?
Because of its indeterminate nature, his crime can be destroyed.
Therefore, I have given King Ajatashatru a determined mind.

At that time, the great king went to the place between the twin sala trees, approached the Buddha, and looked up at the Tathagata's thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, which were like a magnificent golden mountain.
At that time, the World-Honored One emitted eight kinds of sounds and said:
Great King!
At that time, Ajatashatru looked around and thought:
Who is the great king in this great assembly?
Since I have committed a rebellious crime and have no merit, the Tathagata should not be calling me the great king.
At that time, the Tathagata again called out:
Great King Ajatashatru!
When the king heard this, he was overjoyed and said:
The TathÄgata's concern for me today is truly a sign that the TathÄgata's great compassion and pity for all beings is impartial and without distinction.
He addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
My doubts are now completely gone, and I know for certain that the TathÄgata is truly the unsurpassed great teacher of all beings.
At that time, Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said to Bodhisattva Sarva-DhÄraá¹‡Ä«-MukhÄ-DhÄraá¹‡Ä«:

At that time, King AjÄtaÅ›atru addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Even if I were now to be able to sit, rise, and eat and drink with the Brahma King and Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, I would not be so delighted;
but to be able to receive the TathÄgata's words of concern is deeply gratifying.
At that time, King Ajatashatru offered banners, canopies, incense, flowers, and music, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and circumambulated him three times to the right.
After paying homage, he sat to one side.
At that time, the Buddha told King Ajatashatru:
Great King!
I will now explain the essentials of the true Dharma to you. You should listen single-mindedly and attentively.
Ordinary people should always focus their minds on contemplating the body in twenty ways:
First, my body is empty and lacks impurity;
Second, it lacks the foundation of all wholesome roots;
Third, my birth and death have not yet been tamed;
Fourth, falling into deep pits, there is no place that is not feared;
Fifth, by what means can I see the Buddha-nature?
Sixth, how can I cultivate concentration to see the Buddha-nature?
Seventh, birth and death are always suffering, impermanent, and impure;
Eighth, the eight difficulties are difficult to escape from;
Ninth, always being pursued by enemies;
Tenth, there is not a single dharma that can prevent future existences;
Eleventh, not yet attaining liberation from the three evil destinies;
Twelfth, fully possessing various evil and deviant views;
Thirteenth, also not yet establishing a ford to cross the five heinous crimes;
Fourteenth, the end of birth and death is boundless, not yet reaching its edge;
Fifteenth, without creating karma, one does not obtain its fruits;
Sixteenth, there is no self-creation and others experiencing the fruits;
Seventeenth, without creating the causes of happiness, there will ultimately be no happy fruits;
Eighteenth, if one creates karma, its fruits will never be lost;
Nineteenth, born from ignorance, one also dies due to causes;
Twentieth, always being heedless in the past, present, and future.
Great King!
Ordinary people should always contemplate this body in these twenty ways.
Having made these contemplations, they do not delight in birth and death;
If one does not delight in saá¹ƒsÄra, then one attains tranquility and insight.
At that time, one sequentially observes the arising, abiding, and ceasing characteristics of the mind.
Sequentially observing the arising, abiding, and ceasing characteristics of the mind, concentration, wisdom, diligence, and precepts are also like this.

Having observed arising, abiding, and ceasing, one knows the characteristics of the mind up to the characteristics of the precepts, and will never do evil, and has no fear of death or the three evil destinies.
If one does not concentrate the mind to observe these twenty matters, the mind will be unrestrained and will create all kinds of evil.
AjÄtaÅ›atru said:
According to my understanding of the meaning of the Buddha's teachings, I have never before observed these twenty matters, and therefore have created many evils.
Because of creating many evils, there is then fear of death and the three evil destinies.
World-Honored One!
I have invited misfortune and created this grave evil. My innocent father, the king, was unjustly harmed by me.
These twenty matters, whether contemplated or not, will definitely lead to falling into AvÄ«ci Hell.
The Buddha told the great king:
All dharmas are by nature impermanent and without determination. Why do you say that one will definitely fall into AvÄ«ci Hell?
King AjÄtaÅ›atru addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If all dharmas have no fixed characteristics, then the crime of killing committed by me should also not be fixed.
If killing is fixed, then all dharmas are not unfixed.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Excellent, excellent!
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, say that all dharmas have no fixed characteristics, and you are also able to understand that killing is also not fixed.
Therefore, you should know:
Killing has no fixed characteristics.
Great King!
As you have said:
'The innocent father king was unjustly harmed.'
Who is the father?
But they mistakenly give rise to the notion of father towards the five aggregates of beings in the nominal sense.
Among the twelve sense fields and eighteen elements, which one is the father?
If form is the father, the four aggregates should not be;
if the four are the father, form should also not be.
If form and non-form combine to be the father, there is no such possibility.
Why is it so?
Because form and non-form have no nature of combining.
Great King!
Ordinary beings give rise to the notion of father towards this form aggregate in vain. Such a form aggregate is also not to be harmed.
Why is it so?
Form has ten kinds.
Among these ten kinds, only form is visible, can be held, can be weighed, can be measured, can be pulled, and can be bound.
Although it can be seen and bound, its nature does not abide.
Because it does not abide, it cannot be seen, cannot be grasped, cannot be weighed, and cannot be pulled or bound.
The characteristics of form are like this. How can it be killed?
If form is the father, and it can be killed, harmed, and incur retribution, the other nine should not be so;
if the nine are not so, then there should be no crime.
Great King!
Form has three kinds:
past, future, and present.
The past and present cannot be harmed.
Why is it so?
Because the past is past, and the present is momentary,
preventing the future is called killing.
Thus, for one form, there may be that which can be killed, or that which cannot be killed.
If there is killing and not killing, form is then not definite.
If form is not definite, killing is also not definite;
because killing is not definite, retribution is also not definite.
How can it be said that one definitely enters hell?
Great King!
All the sinful karma created by sentient beings has two kinds:
one is light, and the other is heavy.
If it is created by mind and mouth, it is called light;
Actions done with body, speech, and mind are called heavy.
Great King!
If one thinks in the mind, speaks with the mouth, but does not act with the body, the retribution one receives is light.
Great King!
In the past, you did not order the killing, but only said to cut off his feet.
Great King!
If you ordered a servant to stand and cut off the king's head, even if it were cut off while sitting, you would not be guilty, let alone if the king did not order it, how could he be guilty?
If the king is guilty, then the World-Honored Buddhas should also be guilty.
Why is it so?
Your father, King BimbisÄra, once planted various wholesome roots with the Buddhas. Therefore, he is now able to occupy the position of king.
If the Buddhas did not accept his offerings, he would not be a king;
if he were not a king, you would not be able to harm the country.
If you are guilty of killing your father, then we Buddhas should also be guilty.
If the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, do not incur offenses, why do you alone incur offenses?
Great King!
In the past, BimbisÄra had an evil mind. He went to Mount Vipula to hunt deer. He searched everywhere but found nothing. He only saw a sage who was fully endowed with the five supernatural powers.
Having seen him, he gave rise to anger and an evil mind:
The reason I cannot hunt now is precisely because of this person.
He drove him away and ordered his attendants to kill him.
As the man was about to die, he gave rise to an angry and evil mind, lost his supernatural powers, and made a vow:
I am truly innocent. You have wantonly harmed me with your mind and mouth.
In the future, I will also do the same and harm you with my mind and mouth.
When the king heard this, he immediately gave rise to a repentant mind and made offerings to the dead body.
This king thus received a light punishment and did not fall into hell.

Great King!

Great King!
It is like a person holding up a mirror and seeing their own face. A foolish person would consider it a real face, but a wise person understands and knows it is not true.
Killing is also like this. Ordinary people consider it real, but the Buddhas and World-Honored Ones know it is not true.
Great King!
It is like a mirage in the heat. A foolish person would consider it water, but a wise person understands and knows it is not water.
Killing is also like this. Ordinary people consider it real, but the buddhas and world-honored ones know it to be not true.
Great King!
Like a gandharva city, foolish people consider it real, but the wise understand and know it to be not true.
Killing is also like this. Ordinary people consider it real, but the buddhas and world-honored ones know it to be not true.
Great King!
Like a person in a dream experiencing the five desires and pleasures, foolish people consider it real, but the wise understand and know it to be not true.

Great King!
The method of killing, the act of killing, the killer, the fruits of killing, and liberation, I understand them all, and so there is no sin.

What is meant by the conduct of infants?

Unable to rise, stay, come, go, or speak, this is called an infant.
The Tathagata is also like this. As for being unable to rise, the Tathagata will never give rise to the characteristics of dharmas;

As for being unable to go, the Tathagata has already arrived at great parinirvÄá¹‡a;

Why is this?
That which can be spoken of is called conditioned dharmas;
The World-Honored Tathagata is not conditioned, and therefore has nothing to say.
Moreover, to be without speech is like an infant whose language is not yet clear. Although there is speech, it is actually also without speech.
The TathÄgata is also like this. The unclear speech refers to the secret words of the buddhas.
Although there is something spoken, sentient beings do not understand, and therefore it is called without speech.
Moreover, an infant is not one with the name and object, and does not yet know the correct language.
Although the name and object are not one, and one does not yet know the correct language, it is not that one does not thereby come to know the object.

The TathÄgata is also like this. All sentient beings have different languages according to their different countries, and the TathÄgata skillfully speaks according to them, also causing all to thereby come to understand.
Moreover, an infant is able to speak the great characters.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He speaks the great characters, which are called 'bhava' and 'prabhava.'
'Prabhava' refers to the conditioned;
'bhava' refers to the unconditioned.
This is called an infant.
'Prabhava' refers to impermanence;
Ba means permanence.
When the TathÄgata speaks of permanence, sentient beings, upon hearing it, abandon impermanence for the sake of the permanent Dharma. This is called the conduct of an infant.
Moreover, an infant does not know about suffering and joy, day and night, father and mother.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. For the sake of sentient beings, they do not see suffering and joy, have no concept of day and night, and their minds are impartial towards all sentient beings, thus having no concept of parents, close relatives, and so forth.
Moreover, an infant cannot perform large or small tasks.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Bodhisattvas do not create the karma of birth and death. This is called not performing great deeds.
Great deeds refer to the five heinous crimes. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas will never commit the five heinous crimes.
Small deeds refer to the mind of the two vehicles. Bodhisattvas will never abandon the mind of enlightenment and become Å›rÄvakas or pratyekabuddhas.
Moreover, as for the practice of infants, when an infant cries, its parents immediately take a yellow leaf from a willow tree and say to it:
'Don't cry, don't cry.
I will give you gold.'
When the infant sees it, it thinks it is real gold, and so it stops crying. However, this yellow leaf is not really gold.
When the infant sees wooden cows, horses, men, and women, it also gives rise to thoughts of men and women and stops crying.
It is not really men and women. Because of giving rise to such thoughts of men and women, it is called an infant.

The TathÄgata is also like this. If there are sentient beings who wish to create various evils, the TathÄgata will expound for them the permanence, bliss, self, and purity of the Thirty-three Heavens, the freedom to enjoy oneself, to receive the pleasures of the five desires in wonderful palaces, and for the six sense faculties to encounter nothing but bliss.
Because sentient beings hear of such bliss, their minds give rise to craving and delight, cease from doing evil, and diligently create the good karma of the thirty-three heavens.
It is truly birth and death, impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure, but in order to save sentient beings, the Buddha skillfully teaches that it is permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Moreover, as for infants, if there are sentient beings who are weary of birth and death, the TathÄgata will then expound the two vehicles for them.

Just as that infant, with regard to a wooden man or woman, forms the notion of a man or woman;

If the Buddha TathÄgatas spoke of the non-existence of sentient beings, all sentient beings would then fall into wrong views.
Therefore, the TathÄgatas speak of the existence of sentient beings.
Those who form the notion of sentient beings within sentient beings are unable to destroy the notion of sentient beings;

because one attains such a great parinirvÄá¹‡a, one stops crying.
